speaker: CYMBELINE
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: CYMBELINE
text_entry: SCENE I. Elsinore. A platform before the castle.

speaker: CYMBELINE
text_entry: FRANCISCO at his post. Enter to him BERNARDO

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: Who\'s there?

speaker: FRANCISCO
text_entry: Nay, answer me: stand, and unfold yourself.

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: Long live the king!

speaker: FRANCISCO
text_entry: Bernardo?

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: He.

speaker: FRANCISCO
text_entry: You come most carefully upon your hour.

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: \'Tis now struck twelve; get thee to bed, Francisco.

speaker: FRANCISCO
text_entry: For this relief much thanks: \'tis bitter cold,

speaker: FRANCISCO
text_entry: And I am sick at heart.

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: Have you had quiet guard?

speaker: FRANCISCO
text_entry: Not a mouse stirring.

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: Well, good night.

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: If you do meet Horatio and Marcellus,

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: The rivals of my watch, bid them make haste.

speaker: FRANCISCO
text_entry: I think I hear them. Stand, ho! Who\'s there?

speaker: FRANCISCO
text_entry: Enter HORATIO and MARCELLUS

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Friends to this ground.

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: And liegemen to the Dane.

speaker: FRANCISCO
text_entry: Give you good night.

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: O, farewell, honest soldier:

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: Who hath relieved you?

speaker: FRANCISCO
text_entry: Bernardo has my place.

speaker: FRANCISCO
text_entry: Give you good night.

speaker: FRANCISCO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: Holla! Bernardo!

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: Say,

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: What, is Horatio there?

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: A piece of him.

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: Welcome, Horatio: welcome, good Marcellus.

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: What, has this thing appear\'d again to-night?

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: I have seen nothing.

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: Horatio says \'tis but our fantasy,

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: And will not let belief take hold of him

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: Touching this dreaded sight, twice seen of us:

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: Therefore I have entreated him along

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: With us to watch the minutes of this night;

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: That if again this apparition come,

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: He may approve our eyes and speak to it.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Tush, tush, \'twill not appear.

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: Sit down awhile;

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: And let us once again assail your ears,

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: That are so fortified against our story

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: What we have two nights seen.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Well, sit we down,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: And let us hear Bernardo speak of this.

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: Last night of all,

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: When yond same star that\'s westward from the pole

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: Had made his course to illume that part of heaven

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: Where now it burns, Marcellus and myself,

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: The bell then beating one,--

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: Enter Ghost

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: Peace, break thee off; look, where it comes again!

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: In the same figure, like the king that\'s dead.

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: Thou art a scholar; speak to it, Horatio.

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: Looks it not like the king?  mark it, Horatio.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Most like: it harrows me with fear and wonder.

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: It would be spoke to.

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: Question it, Horatio.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: What art thou that usurp\'st this time of night,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Together with that fair and warlike form

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: In which the majesty of buried Denmark

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Did sometimes march? by heaven I charge thee, speak!

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: It is offended.

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: See, it stalks away!

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Stay! speak, speak! I charge thee, speak!

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Exit Ghost

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: \'Tis gone, and will not answer.

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: How now, Horatio! you tremble and look pale:

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: Is not this something more than fantasy?

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: What think you on\'t?

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Before my God, I might not this believe

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Without the sensible and true avouch

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Of mine own eyes.

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: Is it not like the king?

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: As thou art to thyself:

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Such was the very armour he had on

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: When he the ambitious Norway combated;

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: So frown\'d he once, when, in an angry parle,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: He smote the sledded Polacks on the ice.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: \'Tis strange.

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: Thus twice before, and jump at this dead hour,

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: With martial stalk hath he gone by our watch.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: In what particular thought to work I know not;

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: But in the gross and scope of my opinion,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: This bodes some strange eruption to our state.

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: Good now, sit down, and tell me, he that knows,

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: Why this same strict and most observant watch

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: So nightly toils the subject of the land,

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: And why such daily cast of brazen cannon,

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: And foreign mart for implements of war;

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: Why such impress of shipwrights, whose sore task

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: Does not divide the Sunday from the week;

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: What might be toward, that this sweaty haste

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: Doth make the night joint-labourer with the day:

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: Who is\'t that can inform me?

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: That can I;

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: At least, the whisper goes so. Our last king,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Whose image even but now appear\'d to us,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Was, as you know, by Fortinbras of Norway,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Thereto prick\'d on by a most emulate pride,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Dared to the combat; in which our valiant Hamlet--

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: For so this side of our known world esteem\'d him--

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Did slay this Fortinbras; who by a seal\'d compact,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Well ratified by law and heraldry,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Did forfeit, with his life, all those his lands

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Which he stood seized of, to the conqueror:

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Against the which, a moiety competent

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Was gaged by our king; which had return\'d

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: To the inheritance of Fortinbras,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Had he been vanquisher; as, by the same covenant,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: And carriage of the article design\'d,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: His fell to Hamlet. Now, sir, young Fortinbras,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Of unimproved mettle hot and full,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Hath in the skirts of Norway here and there

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Shark\'d up a list of lawless resolutes,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: For food and diet, to some enterprise

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: That hath a stomach in\'t; which is no other--

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: As it doth well appear unto our state--

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: But to recover of us, by strong hand

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: And terms compulsatory, those foresaid lands

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: So by his father lost: and this, I take it,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Is the main motive of our preparations,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: The source of this our watch and the chief head

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Of this post-haste and romage in the land.

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: I think it be no other but e\'en so:

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: Well may it sort that this portentous figure

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: Comes armed through our watch; so like the king

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: That was and is the question of these wars.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: A mote it is to trouble the mind\'s eye.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: In the most high and palmy state of Rome,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: A little ere the mightiest Julius fell,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: The graves stood tenantless and the sheeted dead

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Did squeak and gibber in the Roman streets:

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: As stars with trains of fire and dews of blood,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Disasters in the sun; and the moist star

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Upon whose influence Neptune\'s empire stands

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Was sick almost to doomsday with eclipse:

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: And even the like precurse of fierce events,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: As harbingers preceding still the fates

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: And prologue to the omen coming on,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Have heaven and earth together demonstrated

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Unto our climatures and countrymen.--

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: But soft, behold! lo, where it comes again!

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Re-enter Ghost

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: I\'ll cross it, though it blast me. Stay, illusion!

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: If thou hast any sound, or use of voice,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Speak to me:

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: If there be any good thing to be done,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: That may to thee do ease and grace to me,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Speak to me:

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Cock crows

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: If thou art privy to thy country\'s fate,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Which, happily, foreknowing may avoid, O, speak!

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Or if thou hast uphoarded in thy life

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Extorted treasure in the womb of earth,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: For which, they say, you spirits oft walk in death,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Speak of it: stay, and speak! Stop it, Marcellus.

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: Shall I strike at it with my partisan?

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Do, if it will not stand.

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: \'Tis here!

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: \'Tis here!

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: \'Tis gone!

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: Exit Ghost

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: We do it wrong, being so majestical,

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: To offer it the show of violence;

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: For it is, as the air, invulnerable,

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: And our vain blows malicious mockery.

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: It was about to speak, when the cock crew.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: And then it started like a guilty thing

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Upon a fearful summons. I have heard,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: The cock, that is the trumpet to the morn,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Doth with his lofty and shrill-sounding throat

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Awake the god of day; and, at his warning,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Whether in sea or fire, in earth or air,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: The extravagant and erring spirit hies

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: To his confine: and of the truth herein

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: This present object made probation.

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: It faded on the crowing of the cock.

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: Some say that ever \'gainst that season comes

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: Wherein our Saviour\'s birth is celebrated,

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: The bird of dawning singeth all night long:

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: And then, they say, no spirit dares stir abroad;

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: The nights are wholesome; then no planets strike,

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: No fairy takes, nor witch hath power to charm,

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: So hallow\'d and so gracious is the time.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: So have I heard and do in part believe it.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: But, look, the morn, in russet mantle clad,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Walks o\'er the dew of yon high eastward hill:

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Break we our watch up; and by my advice,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Let us impart what we have seen to-night

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Unto young Hamlet; for, upon my life,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: This spirit, dumb to us, will speak to him.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Do you consent we shall acquaint him with it,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: As needful in our loves, fitting our duty?

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: Let\'s do\'t, I pray; and I this morning know

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: Where we shall find him most conveniently.

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: SCENE II. A room of state in the castle.

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: Enter KING CLAUDIUS, QUEEN GERTRUDE, HAMLET,  POLONIUS, LAERTES, VOLTIMAND, CORNELIUS, Lords, and Attendants

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Though yet of Hamlet our dear brother\'s death

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: The memory be green, and that it us befitted

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: To bear our hearts in grief and our whole kingdom

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: To be contracted in one brow of woe,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Yet so far hath discretion fought with nature

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: That we with wisest sorrow think on him,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Together with remembrance of ourselves.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Therefore our sometime sister, now our queen,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: The imperial jointress to this warlike state,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Have we, as \'twere with a defeated joy,--

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: With an auspicious and a dropping eye,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: With mirth in funeral and with dirge in marriage,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: In equal scale weighing delight and dole,--

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Taken to wife: nor have we herein barr\'d

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Your better wisdoms, which have freely gone

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: With this affair along. For all, our thanks.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Now follows, that you know, young Fortinbras,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Holding a weak supposal of our worth,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Or thinking by our late dear brother\'s death

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Our state to be disjoint and out of frame,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Colleagued with the dream of his advantage,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: He hath not fail\'d to pester us with message,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Importing the surrender of those lands

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Lost by his father, with all bonds of law,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: To our most valiant brother. So much for him.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Now for ourself and for this time of meeting:

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Thus much the business is: we have here writ

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: To Norway, uncle of young Fortinbras,--

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Who, impotent and bed-rid, scarcely hears

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Of this his nephew\'s purpose,--to suppress

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: His further gait herein; in that the levies,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: The lists and full proportions, are all made

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Out of his subject: and we here dispatch

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: You, good Cornelius, and you, Voltimand,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: For bearers of this greeting to old Norway;

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Giving to you no further personal power

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: To business with the king, more than the scope

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Of these delated articles allow.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Farewell, and let your haste commend your duty.

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: In that and all things will we show our duty.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: We doubt it nothing: heartily farewell.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Exeunt VOLTIMAND and CORNELIUS

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: And now, Laertes, what\'s the news with you?

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: You told us of some suit; what is\'t, Laertes?

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: You cannot speak of reason to the Dane,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: And loose your voice: what wouldst thou beg, Laertes,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: That shall not be my offer, not thy asking?

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: The head is not more native to the heart,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: The hand more instrumental to the mouth,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Than is the throne of Denmark to thy father.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: What wouldst thou have, Laertes?

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: My dread lord,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Your leave and favour to return to France;

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: From whence though willingly I came to Denmark,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: To show my duty in your coronation,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Yet now, I must confess, that duty done,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: My thoughts and wishes bend again toward France

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: And bow them to your gracious leave and pardon.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Have you your father\'s leave? What says Polonius?

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: He hath, my lord, wrung from me my slow leave

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: By laboursome petition, and at last

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Upon his will I seal\'d my hard consent:

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: I do beseech you, give him leave to go.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Take thy fair hour, Laertes; time be thine,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: And thy best graces spend it at thy will!

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: But now, my cousin Hamlet, and my son,--

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: [Aside]  A little more than kin, and less than kind.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: How is it that the clouds still hang on you?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Not so, my lord; I am too much i\' the sun.

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: Good Hamlet, cast thy nighted colour off,

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: And let thine eye look like a friend on Denmark.

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: Do not for ever with thy vailed lids

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: Seek for thy noble father in the dust:

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: Thou know\'st \'tis common; all that lives must die,

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: Passing through nature to eternity.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Ay, madam, it is common.

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: If it be,

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: Why seems it so particular with thee?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Seems, madam! nay it is; I know not \'seems.\'

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: \'Tis not alone my inky cloak, good mother,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Nor customary suits of solemn black,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Nor windy suspiration of forced breath,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: No, nor the fruitful river in the eye,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Nor the dejected \'havior of the visage,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Together with all forms, moods, shapes of grief,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: That can denote me truly: these indeed seem,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: For they are actions that a man might play:

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: But I have that within which passeth show;

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: These but the trappings and the suits of woe.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: \'Tis sweet and commendable in your nature, Hamlet,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: To give these mourning duties to your father:

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: But, you must know, your father lost a father;

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: That father lost, lost his, and the survivor bound

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: In filial obligation for some term

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: To do obsequious sorrow: but to persever

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: In obstinate condolement is a course

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Of impious stubbornness; \'tis unmanly grief;

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: It shows a will most incorrect to heaven,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: A heart unfortified, a mind impatient,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: An understanding simple and unschool\'d:

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: For what we know must be and is as common

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: As any the most vulgar thing to sense,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Why should we in our peevish opposition

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Take it to heart? Fie! \'tis a fault to heaven,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: A fault against the dead, a fault to nature,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: To reason most absurd: whose common theme

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Is death of fathers, and who still hath cried,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: From the first corse till he that died to-day,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: \'This must be so.\' We pray you, throw to earth

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: This unprevailing woe, and think of us

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: As of a father: for let the world take note,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: You are the most immediate to our throne;

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: And with no less nobility of love

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Than that which dearest father bears his son,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Do I impart toward you. For your intent

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: In going back to school in Wittenberg,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: It is most retrograde to our desire:

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: And we beseech you, bend you to remain

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Here, in the cheer and comfort of our eye,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Our chiefest courtier, cousin, and our son.

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: Let not thy mother lose her prayers, Hamlet:

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: I pray thee, stay with us; go not to Wittenberg.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I shall in all my best obey you, madam.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Why, \'tis a loving and a fair reply:

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Be as ourself in Denmark. Madam, come;

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: This gentle and unforced accord of Hamlet

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Sits smiling to my heart: in grace whereof,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: No jocund health that Denmark drinks to-day,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: But the great cannon to the clouds shall tell,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: And the king\'s rouse the heavens all bruit again,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Re-speaking earthly thunder. Come away.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Exeunt all but HAMLET

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: O, that this too too solid flesh would melt

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Thaw and resolve itself into a dew!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Or that the Everlasting had not fix\'d

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: His canon \'gainst self-slaughter! O God! God!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: How weary, stale, flat and unprofitable,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Seem to me all the uses of this world!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Fie on\'t! ah fie! \'tis an unweeded garden,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: That grows to seed; things rank and gross in nature

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Possess it merely. That it should come to this!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: But two months dead: nay, not so much, not two:

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: So excellent a king; that was, to this,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Hyperion to a satyr; so loving to my mother

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: That he might not beteem the winds of heaven

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Visit her face too roughly. Heaven and earth!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Must I remember? why, she would hang on him,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: As if increase of appetite had grown

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: By what it fed on: and yet, within a month--

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Let me not think on\'t--Frailty, thy name is woman!--

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: A little month, or ere those shoes were old

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: With which she follow\'d my poor father\'s body,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Like Niobe, all tears:--why she, even she--

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: O, God! a beast, that wants discourse of reason,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Would have mourn\'d longer--married with my uncle,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: My father\'s brother, but no more like my father

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Than I to Hercules: within a month:

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Ere yet the salt of most unrighteous tears

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Had left the flushing in her galled eyes,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: She married. O, most wicked speed, to post

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: With such dexterity to incestuous sheets!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: It is not nor it cannot come to good:

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: But break, my heart; for I must hold my tongue.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Enter HORATIO, MARCELLUS, and BERNARDO

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Hail to your lordship!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I am glad to see you well:

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Horatio,--or I do forget myself.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: The same, my lord, and your poor servant ever.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Sir, my good friend; I\'ll change that name with you:

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: And what make you from Wittenberg, Horatio? Marcellus?

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: My good lord--

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I am very glad to see you. Good even, sir.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: But what, in faith, make you from Wittenberg?

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: A truant disposition, good my lord.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I would not hear your enemy say so,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Nor shall you do mine ear that violence,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: To make it truster of your own report

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Against yourself: I know you are no truant.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: But what is your affair in Elsinore?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: We\'ll teach you to drink deep ere you depart.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: My lord, I came to see your father\'s funeral.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I pray thee, do not mock me, fellow-student;

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I think it was to see my mother\'s wedding.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Indeed, my lord, it follow\'d hard upon.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Thrift, thrift, Horatio! the funeral baked meats

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Did coldly furnish forth the marriage tables.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Would I had met my dearest foe in heaven

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Or ever I had seen that day, Horatio!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: My father!--methinks I see my father.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Where, my lord?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: In my mind\'s eye, Horatio.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: I saw him once; he was a goodly king.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: He was a man, take him for all in all,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I shall not look upon his like again.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: My lord, I think I saw him yesternight.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Saw? who?

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: My lord, the king your father.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: The king my father!

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Season your admiration for awhile

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: With an attent ear, till I may deliver,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Upon the witness of these gentlemen,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: This marvel to you.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: For God\'s love, let me hear.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Two nights together had these gentlemen,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Marcellus and Bernardo, on their watch,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: In the dead vast and middle of the night,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Been thus encounter\'d. A figure like your father,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Armed at point exactly, cap-a-pe,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Appears before them, and with solemn march

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Goes slow and stately by them: thrice he walk\'d

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: By their oppress\'d and fear-surprised eyes,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Within his truncheon\'s length; whilst they, distilled

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Almost to jelly with the act of fear,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Stand dumb and speak not to him. This to me

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: In dreadful secrecy impart they did;

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: And I with them the third night kept the watch;

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Where, as they had deliver\'d, both in time,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Form of the thing, each word made true and good,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: The apparition comes: I knew your father;

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: These hands are not more like.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: But where was this?

speaker: MARCELLUS
text_entry: My lord, upon the platform where we watch\'d.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Did you not speak to it?

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: My lord, I did;

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: But answer made it none: yet once methought

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: It lifted up its head and did address

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Itself to motion, like as it would speak;

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: But even then the morning cock crew loud,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: And at the sound it shrunk in haste away,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: And vanish\'d from our sight.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: \'Tis very strange.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: As I do live, my honour\'d lord, \'tis true;

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: And we did think it writ down in our duty

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: To let you know of it.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Indeed, indeed, sirs, but this troubles me.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Hold you the watch to-night?

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: We do, my lord.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Arm\'d, say you?

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: Arm\'d, my lord.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: From top to toe?

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: My lord, from head to foot.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Then saw you not his face?

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: O, yes, my lord; he wore his beaver up.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: What, look\'d he frowningly?

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: A countenance more in sorrow than in anger.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Pale or red?

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Nay, very pale.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: And fix\'d his eyes upon you?

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Most constantly.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I would I had been there.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: It would have much amazed you.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Very like, very like. Stay\'d it long?

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: While one with moderate haste might tell a hundred.

speaker: BERNARDO
text_entry: Longer, longer.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Not when I saw\'t.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: His beard was grizzled--no?

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: It was, as I have seen it in his life,

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: A sable silver\'d.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I will watch to-night;

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Perchance \'twill walk again.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: I warrant it will.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: If it assume my noble father\'s person,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I\'ll speak to it, though hell itself should gape

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: And bid me hold my peace. I pray you all,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: If you have hitherto conceal\'d this sight,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Let it be tenable in your silence still;

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: And whatsoever else shall hap to-night,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Give it an understanding, but no tongue:

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I will requite your loves. So, fare you well:

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Upon the platform, \'twixt eleven and twelve,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I\'ll visit you.

speaker: All
text_entry: Our duty to your honour.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Your loves, as mine to you: farewell.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Exeunt all but HAMLET

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: My father\'s spirit in arms! all is not well;

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I doubt some foul play: would the night were come!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Till then sit still, my soul: foul deeds will rise,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Though all the earth o\'erwhelm them, to men\'s eyes.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Exit

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: SCENE III. A room in Polonius\' house.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Enter LAERTES and OPHELIA

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: My necessaries are embark\'d: farewell:

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: And, sister, as the winds give benefit

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: And convoy is assistant, do not sleep,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: But let me hear from you.

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: Do you doubt that?

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: For Hamlet and the trifling of his favour,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Hold it a fashion and a toy in blood,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: A violet in the youth of primy nature,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Forward, not permanent, sweet, not lasting,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: The perfume and suppliance of a minute; No more.

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: No more but so?

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Think it no more;

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: For nature, crescent, does not grow alone

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: In thews and bulk, but, as this temple waxes,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: The inward service of the mind and soul

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Grows wide withal. Perhaps he loves you now,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: And now no soil nor cautel doth besmirch

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: The virtue of his will: but you must fear,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: His greatness weigh\'d, his will is not his own;

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: For he himself is subject to his birth:

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: He may not, as unvalued persons do,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Carve for himself; for on his choice depends

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: The safety and health of this whole state;

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: And therefore must his choice be circumscribed

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Unto the voice and yielding of that body

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Whereof he is the head. Then if he says he loves you,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: It fits your wisdom so far to believe it

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: As he in his particular act and place

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: May give his saying deed; which is no further

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Than the main voice of Denmark goes withal.

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Then weigh what loss your honour may sustain,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: If with too credent ear you list his songs,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Or lose your heart, or your chaste treasure open

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: To his unmaster\'d importunity.

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Fear it, Ophelia, fear it, my dear sister,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: And keep you in the rear of your affection,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Out of the shot and danger of desire.

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: The chariest maid is prodigal enough,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: If she unmask her beauty to the moon:

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Virtue itself \'scapes not calumnious strokes:

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: The canker galls the infants of the spring,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Too oft before their buttons be disclosed,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: And in the morn and liquid dew of youth

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Contagious blastments are most imminent.

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Be wary then; best safety lies in fear:

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Youth to itself rebels, though none else near.

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: I shall the effect of this good lesson keep,

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: As watchman to my heart. But, good my brother,

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: Do not, as some ungracious pastors do,

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: Show me the steep and thorny way to heaven;

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: Whiles, like a puff\'d and reckless libertine,

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: Himself the primrose path of dalliance treads,

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: And recks not his own rede.

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: O, fear me not.

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: I stay too long: but here my father comes.

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Enter POLONIUS

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: A double blessing is a double grace,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Occasion smiles upon a second leave.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Yet here, Laertes! aboard, aboard, for shame!

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: The wind sits in the shoulder of your sail,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And you are stay\'d for. There; my blessing with thee!

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And these few precepts in thy memory

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: See thou character. Give thy thoughts no tongue,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Nor any unproportioned thought his act.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Be thou familiar, but by no means vulgar.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Those friends thou hast, and their adoption tried,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Grapple them to thy soul with hoops of steel;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: But do not dull thy palm with entertainment

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Of each new-hatch\'d, unfledged comrade. Beware

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Of entrance to a quarrel, but being in,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Bear\'t that the opposed may beware of thee.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Give every man thy ear, but few thy voice;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Take each man\'s censure, but reserve thy judgment.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Costly thy habit as thy purse can buy,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: But not express\'d in fancy; rich, not gaudy;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: For the apparel oft proclaims the man,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And they in France of the best rank and station

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Are of a most select and generous chief in that.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Neither a borrower nor a lender be;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: For loan oft loses both itself and friend,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And borrowing dulls the edge of husbandry.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: This above all: to thine ownself be true,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And it must follow, as the night the day,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Thou canst not then be false to any man.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Farewell: my blessing season this in thee!

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Most humbly do I take my leave, my lord.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: The time invites you; go; your servants tend.

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Farewell, Ophelia; and remember well

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: What I have said to you.

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: \'Tis in my memory lock\'d,

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: And you yourself shall keep the key of it.

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Farewell.

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Exit

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: What is\'t, Ophelia, be hath said to you?

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: So please you, something touching the Lord Hamlet.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Marry, well bethought:

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: \'Tis told me, he hath very oft of late

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Given private time to you; and you yourself

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Have of your audience been most free and bounteous:

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: If it be so, as so \'tis put on me,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And that in way of caution, I must tell you,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: You do not understand yourself so clearly

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: As it behoves my daughter and your honour.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: What is between you? give me up the truth.

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: He hath, my lord, of late made many tenders

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: Of his affection to me.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Affection! pooh! you speak like a green girl,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Unsifted in such perilous circumstance.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Do you believe his tenders, as you call them?

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: I do not know, my lord, what I should think.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Marry, I\'ll teach you: think yourself a baby;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: That you have ta\'en these tenders for true pay,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Which are not sterling. Tender yourself more dearly;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Or--not to crack the wind of the poor phrase,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Running it thus--you\'ll tender me a fool.

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: My lord, he hath importuned me with love

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: In honourable fashion.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Ay, fashion you may call it; go to, go to.

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: And hath given countenance to his speech, my lord,

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: With almost all the holy vows of heaven.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Ay, springes to catch woodcocks. I do know,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: When the blood burns, how prodigal the soul

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Lends the tongue vows: these blazes, daughter,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Giving more light than heat, extinct in both,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Even in their promise, as it is a-making,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: You must not take for fire. From this time

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Be somewhat scanter of your maiden presence;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Set your entreatments at a higher rate

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Than a command to parley. For Lord Hamlet,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Believe so much in him, that he is young

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And with a larger tether may he walk

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Than may be given you: in few, Ophelia,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Do not believe his vows; for they are brokers,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Not of that dye which their investments show,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: But mere implorators of unholy suits,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Breathing like sanctified and pious bawds,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: The better to beguile. This is for all:

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: I would not, in plain terms, from this time forth,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Have you so slander any moment leisure,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: As to give words or talk with the Lord Hamlet.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Look to\'t, I charge you: come your ways.

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: I shall obey, my lord.

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: SCENE IV. The platform.

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: Enter HAMLET, HORATIO, and MARCELLUS

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: The air bites shrewdly; it is very cold.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: It is a nipping and an eager air.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: What hour now?

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: I think it lacks of twelve.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: No, it is struck.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Indeed? I heard it not: then it draws near the season

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Wherein the spirit held his wont to walk.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: A flourish of trumpets, and ordnance shot off, within

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: What does this mean, my lord?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: The king doth wake to-night and takes his rouse,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Keeps wassail, and the swaggering up-spring reels;

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: And, as he drains his draughts of Rhenish down,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: The kettle-drum and trumpet thus bray out

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: The triumph of his pledge.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Is it a custom?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Ay, marry, is\'t:

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: But to my mind, though I am native here

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: And to the manner born, it is a custom

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: More honour\'d in the breach than the observance.

text_entry: Ay, my lord,

speaker: REYNALDO
text_entry: I would know that.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Marry, sir, here\'s my drift;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And I believe, it is a fetch of wit:

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: You laying these slight sullies on my son,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: As \'twere a thing a little soil\'d i\' the working, Mark you,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Your party in converse, him you would sound,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Having ever seen in the prenominate crimes

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: The youth you breathe of guilty, be assured

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: He closes with you in this consequence;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: \'Good sir,\' or so, or \'friend,\' or \'gentleman,\'

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: According to the phrase or the addition

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Of man and country.

speaker: REYNALDO
text_entry: Very good, my lord.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And then, sir, does he this--he does--what was I

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: about to say? By the mass, I was about to say

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: something: where did I leave?

speaker: REYNALDO
text_entry: At \'closes in the consequence,\' at \'friend or so,\'

speaker: REYNALDO
text_entry: and \'gentleman.\'

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: At \'closes in the consequence,\' ay, marry;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: He closes thus: \'I know the gentleman;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: I saw him yesterday, or t\' other day,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Or then, or then; with such, or such; and, as you say,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: There was a\' gaming; there o\'ertook in\'s rouse;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: There falling out at tennis:\' or perchance,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: \'I saw him enter such a house of sale,\'

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Videlicet, a brothel, or so forth.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: See you now;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Your bait of falsehood takes this carp of truth:

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And thus do we of wisdom and of reach,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: With windlasses and with assays of bias,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: By indirections find directions out:

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: So by my former lecture and advice,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Shall you my son. You have me, have you not?

speaker: REYNALDO
text_entry: My lord, I have.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: God be wi\' you; fare you well.

speaker: REYNALDO
text_entry: Good my lord!

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Observe his inclination in yourself.

speaker: REYNALDO
text_entry: I shall, my lord.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And let him ply his music.

speaker: REYNALDO
text_entry: Well, my lord.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Farewell!

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Enter OPHELIA

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: How now, Ophelia! what\'s the matter?

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: O, my lord, my lord, I have been so affrighted!

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: With what, i\' the name of God?

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: My lord, as I was sewing in my closet,

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: Lord Hamlet, with his doublet all unbraced;

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: No hat upon his head; his stockings foul\'d,

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: Ungarter\'d, and down-gyved to his ancle;

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: Pale as his shirt; his knees knocking each other;

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: And with a look so piteous in purport

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: As if he had been loosed out of hell

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: To speak of horrors,--he comes before me.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Mad for thy love?

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: My lord, I do not know;

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: But truly, I do fear it.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: What said he?

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: He took me by the wrist and held me hard;

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: Then goes he to the length of all his arm;

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: And, with his other hand thus o\'er his brow,

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: He falls to such perusal of my face

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: As he would draw it. Long stay\'d he so;

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: At last, a little shaking of mine arm

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: And thrice his head thus waving up and down,

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: He raised a sigh so piteous and profound

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: As it did seem to shatter all his bulk

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: And end his being: that done, he lets me go:

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: And, with his head over his shoulder turn\'d,

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: He seem\'d to find his way without his eyes;

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: For out o\' doors he went without their helps,

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: And, to the last, bended their light on me.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Come, go with me: I will go seek the king.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: This is the very ecstasy of love,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Whose violent property fordoes itself

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And leads the will to desperate undertakings

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: As oft as any passion under heaven

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: That does afflict our natures. I am sorry.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: What, have you given him any hard words of late?

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: No, my good lord, but, as you did command,

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: I did repel his fetters and denied

speaker: OPHELIA
text_entry: His access to me.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: That hath made him mad.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: I am sorry that with better heed and judgment

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: I had not quoted him: I fear\'d he did but trifle,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And meant to wreck thee; but, beshrew my jealousy!

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: By heaven, it is as proper to our age

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: To cast beyond ourselves in our opinions

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: As it is common for the younger sort

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: To lack discretion. Come, go we to the king:

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: This must be known; which, being kept close, might

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: move

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: More grief to hide than hate to utter love.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: SCENE II. A room in the castle.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Enter KING CLAUDIUS, QUEEN GERTRUDE, ROSENCRANTZ, GUILDENSTERN, and Attendants

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Welcome, dear Rosencrantz and Guildenstern!

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Moreover that we much did long to see you,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: The need we have to use you did provoke

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Our hasty sending. Something have you heard

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Of Hamlet\'s transformation; so call it,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Sith nor the exterior nor the inward man

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Resembles that it was. What it should be,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: More than his father\'s death, that thus hath put him

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: So much from the understanding of himself,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: I cannot dream of: I entreat you both,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: That, being of so young days brought up with him,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: And sith so neighbour\'d to his youth and havior,

text_entry: That you vouchsafe your rest here in our court

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Some little time: so by your companies

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: To draw him on to pleasures, and to gather,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: So much as from occasion you may glean,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Whether aught, to us unknown, afflicts him thus,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: That, open\'d, lies within our remedy.

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: Good gentlemen, he hath much talk\'d of you;

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: And sure I am two men there are not living

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: To whom he more adheres. If it will please you

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: To show us so much gentry and good will

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: As to expend your time with us awhile,

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: For the supply and profit of our hope,

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: Your visitation shall receive such thanks

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: As fits a king\'s remembrance.

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: Both your majesties

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: Might, by the sovereign power you have of us,

text_entry: Put your dread pleasures more into command

text_entry: Than to entreaty.

text_entry: To be commanded.

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE

text_entry: Hunts not the trail of policy so sure

text_entry: As it hath used to do, that I have found

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: The very cause of Hamlet\'s lunacy.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: O, speak of that; that do I long to hear.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Give first admittance to the ambassadors;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS

text_entry: He tells me, my dear Gertrude, he hath found

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: The head and source of all your son\'s distemper.

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: I doubt it is no other but the main;

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: His father\'s death, and our o\'erhasty marriage.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Well, we shall sift him.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Welcome, my good friends!

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Say, Voltimand, what from our brother Norway?

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: Most fair return of greetings and desires.

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: Upon our first, he sent out to suppress

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: His nephew\'s levies; which to him appear\'d

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: To be a preparation \'gainst the Polack;

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: But, better look\'d into, he truly found

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: It was against your highness: whereat grieved,

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: That so his sickness, age and impotence

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: Was falsely borne in hand, sends out arrests

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: On Fortinbras; which he, in brief, obeys;

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: Receives rebuke from Norway, and in fine

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: Makes vow before his uncle never more

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: To give the assay of arms against your majesty.

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: Whereon old Norway, overcome with joy,

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: Gives him three thousand crowns in annual fee,

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: And his commission to employ those soldiers,

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: So levied as before, against the Polack:

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: With an entreaty, herein further shown,

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: Giving a paper

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: That it might please you to give quiet pass

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: Through your dominions for this enterprise,

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: On such regards of safety and allowance

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: As therein are set down.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: It likes us well;

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: And at our more consider\'d time well read,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Answer, and think upon this business.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Meantime we thank you for your well-took labour:

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Go to your rest; at night we\'ll feast together:

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Most welcome home!

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: This business is well ended.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: My liege, and madam, to expostulate

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: What majesty should be, what duty is,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Why day is day, night night, and time is time,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Were nothing but to waste night, day and time.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Therefore, since brevity is the soul of wit,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And tediousness the limbs and outward flourishes,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: I will be brief: your noble son is mad:

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Mad call I it; for, to define true madness,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: What is\'t but to be nothing else but mad?

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: But let that go.

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: More matter, with less art.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Madam, I swear I use no art at all.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: That he is mad, \'tis true: \'tis true \'tis pity;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And pity \'tis \'tis true: a foolish figure;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: But farewell it, for I will use no art.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Mad let us grant him, then: and now remains

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: That we find out the cause of this effect,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Or rather say, the cause of this defect,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: For this effect defective comes by cause:

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Thus it remains, and the remainder thus. Perpend.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: I have a daughter--have while she is mine--

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Who, in her duty and obedience, mark,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Hath given me this: now gather, and surmise.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Reads

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: \'To the celestial and my soul\'s idol, the most

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: beautified Ophelia,\'--

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: That\'s an ill phrase, a vile phrase; \'beautified\' is

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: a vile phrase: but you shall hear. Thus:

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Reads

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: \'In her excellent white bosom, these,  and c.\'

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: Came this from Hamlet to her?

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Good madam, stay awhile; I will be faithful.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Reads

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: \'Doubt thou the stars are fire;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Doubt that the sun doth move;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Doubt truth to be a liar;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: But never doubt I love.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: \'O dear Ophelia, I am ill at these numbers;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: I have not art to reckon my groans: but that

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: I love thee best, O most best, believe it. Adieu.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: \'Thine evermore most dear lady, whilst

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: this machine is to him, HAMLET.\'

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: This, in obedience, hath my daughter shown me,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And more above, hath his solicitings,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: As they fell out by time, by means and place,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: All given to mine ear.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: But how hath she

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Received his love?

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: What do you think of me?

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: As of a man faithful and honourable.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: I would fain prove so. But what might you think,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: When I had seen this hot love on the wing--

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: As I perceived it, I must tell you that,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Before my daughter told me--what might you,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Or my dear majesty your queen here, think,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: If I had play\'d the desk or table-book,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Or given my heart a winking, mute and dumb,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Or look\'d upon this love with idle sight;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: What might you think? No, I went round to work,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And my young mistress thus I did bespeak:

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: \'Lord Hamlet is a prince, out of thy star;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: This must not be:\' and then I precepts gave her,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: That she should lock herself from his resort,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Admit no messengers, receive no tokens.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Which done, she took the fruits of my advice;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And he, repulsed--a short tale to make--

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Fell into a sadness, then into a fast,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Thence to a watch, thence into a weakness,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Thence to a lightness, and, by this declension,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Into the madness wherein now he raves,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And all we mourn for.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Do you think \'tis this?

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: It may be, very likely.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Hath there been such a time--I\'d fain know that--

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: That I have positively said \'Tis so,\'

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: When it proved otherwise?

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Not that I know.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: [Pointing to his head and shoulder]

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Take this from this, if this be otherwise:

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: If circumstances lead me, I will find

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Where truth is hid, though it were hid indeed

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Within the centre.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: How may we try it further?

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: You know, sometimes he walks four hours together

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Here in the lobby.

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: So he does indeed.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: At such a time I\'ll loose my daughter to him:

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Be you and I behind an arras then;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Mark the encounter: if he love her not

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And be not from his reason fall\'n thereon,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Let me be no assistant for a state,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: But keep a farm and carters.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: We will try it.

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: But, look, where sadly the poor wretch comes reading.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Away, I do beseech you, both away:

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: I\'ll board him presently.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Exeunt KING CLAUDIUS, QUEEN GERTRUDE, and Attendants

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Enter HAMLET, reading

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: O, give me leave:

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: How does my good Lord Hamlet?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Well, God-a-mercy.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Do you know me, my lord?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Excellent well; you are a fishmonger.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Not I, my lord.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Then I would you were so honest a man.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Honest, my lord!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Ay, sir; to be honest, as this world goes, is to be

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: one man picked out of ten thousand.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: That\'s very true, my lord.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: For if the sun breed maggots in a dead dog, being a

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: god kissing carrion,--Have you a daughter?

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: I have, my lord.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Let her not walk i\' the sun: conception is a

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: blessing: but not as your daughter may conceive.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Friend, look to \'t.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: [Aside]  How say you by that? Still harping on my

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: daughter: yet he knew me not at first; he said I

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: was a fishmonger: he is far gone, far gone: and

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: truly in my youth I suffered much extremity for

speaker: LORD POLONIUS

text_entry: Enter a King and a Queen very lovingly; the Queen  embracing him, and he her. She kneels, and makes  show of protestation unto him. He takes her up,  and declines his head upon her neck: lays him down  upon a bank of flowers: she, seeing him asleep,  leaves him. Anon comes in a fellow, takes off his  crown, kisses it, and pours poison in the King\'s  ears, and exit. The Queen returns; finds the King  dead, and makes passionate action. The Poisoner,  with some two or three Mutes, comes in again,  seeming to lament with her. The dead body is  carried away.
